subject: 05.10 finished
header: First of all, let me apologize for the late and duplicate e-mails last week. I upgraded the server just before sending out the edition and I managed to break the mailserver. At first it did not send out the e-mail. After fixing part of the server I tried to send it again, that did not work either and then, when I finally managed to fix the server, all the messages that were in the queue went out at once.
The Polish Perl Workshop is this weekend in Poznan!.

entries.title: Planet Moose - April 2014
entries.text: The monthly review of Toby Inkster about everything Object Oriented in Perl. New Moose and Moo releases.

entries.title: Concerned about Perl (un)popularity
entries.text: A Reddit user wonders why does Perl slowly loose from it popularity. Many people offer their opinion. Some of them even tell what others should do about it... It is an interesting read, but I wonder what will people actualy do about it?

entries.title: Thunderclap and the buzz for Perl
entries.text: Thunderclap allow you to commit to send a specific tweet (or Facebook share) at a certain time in the future. I started a little experiment with it. If you like it, please join the action.

entries.title: Test::Pretty - Because TAP Is Unnattractive
entries.text: Screenshots with colored output are always much more convencing than a wall of text explaining the advantages of something.

entries.title: Examining the book 'Perl Best Practices'
entries.text: Laufeyjarson has started a series of articles examinig 'The Book' that many people hold as the Holy Bible of Perl programming. He does not seem to agree with every point...

entries.title: Using Perl on Red Hat's OpenShift Cloud
entries.text: Ovid explains how to use this Platform as a Service (PaaS) system to avoid the need to handle sysadmin tasks while building a web application.

entries.title: Covert Redirect Vulnerability with OAuth 2
entries.text: Not Perl specific, but if you write a web application using OAuth 2 and 'Implicit Grant Flow' you might want to check this out.

entries.title: Adopting DateTime::Calendar::Pataphysical
entries.text: A short explanation by Philippe Bruhat how he adopted this module. It is quite simple. You can do it too.

entries.title: Rakudo Star Release 2014.04
entries.text: This is the first Rakudo Star release with support for the MoarVM backend (all module tests pass on supported platforms) along with experimental support for the JVM backend (some module tests fail).

entries.title: 2014.18: More supply ops, loop labels, more async I/O on jvm
Rakudobrew
entries.text: To make it easy to install Rakudo Perl 6

entries.title: When a Space Is Not Just a Space
entries.text: Nick Patch, Perl developer and resident Unicode expert of Shutterstock explains the space.

entries.title: Interview with Christian Walde
entries.text: Viacheslav Tykhanovskyi (vti) conducted a written interview with Mithaldu. It is available at the Pragmatic Perl web site, both in English and in Russian.

entries.title: Split CSV file into multiple small CSV files
entries.text: Separate solution for both horizontal and vertical splitting.
In the following cities: Poznan (PL), Prague (CZ), Oslo (NO), Paris (FR), Kiev (UA), Orlando (FL/USA), Sofia (BG), Fl√∂rli Olten (CH)
